series.series.name: Brush Wolves Already Call Adirondacks Home

abstract.p: Donald P Gigliotti letter opposes reintroduction of wolves to the Adirondacks; says money would better be spent cleaning up air and water pollution in the park

block.p: Would the Adirondacks not be better served if financial resources exhausted examining the feasibility of wolf reintroduction (editorial, Nov. 24) were instead dedicated to restoring the integrity of New York's waterways lost to P.C.B.'s and reclaiming our forests ravaged by acid rain?

Would the Adirondacks not be better served if financial resources exhausted examining the feasibility of wolf reintroduction (editorial, Nov. 24) were instead dedicated to restoring the integrity of New York's waterways lost to P.C.B.'s and reclaiming our forests ravaged by acid rain?

Is it not cruel to release an endangered species into toxic environs? Or could it be that returning the wolf to Adirondack State Park is driven more by public relations rather than the level-headed resolve needed to correct the self-inflicted environmental hazards that will not correct themselves? If we do not save our air and water, the wolf will die and so will we.
DONALD P. GIGLIOTTI Utica, N.Y., Nov. 26, 1996
Brush Wolves Already Call Adirondacks Home
